The conversion of syngas into higher alcohols was examined using bimetallic Rh-Co, Rh-Cu, and multimetallic RhCuPd catalysts, all of which were supported on ZrO2. This process was also studied using a MnOx-promoted Rh/SiO2 catalyst. These experiments were conducted within a temperature range of 225–300 °C, under a pressure of 30 bar, and with a H2/CO ratio of 2. The catalysts were characterized using a variety of physicochemical methods, including Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), X-ray Diffraction (XRD), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and Carbon Monoxide Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (CO DRIFTS). The Rh particle sizes in the fresh catalysts were found to be less than 3 nm. The Rh-Co catalyst supported on ZrO2 exhibited the highest selectivity to ethanol, achieving 38 % at a CO conversion rate of 58 % at 275 °C. This catalyst also demonstrated a chain growth probability of 0.35 for alcohols. A slightly higher chain growth probability was observed with the Rh-MnOx/SiO2 catalyst, although this also resulted in the formation of substantial amounts of acetic acid. Interestingly, this acetic acid could be converted into ketones when RhMnOx was used in conjunction with Pd/ZrO2. Graphical Abstract Keywords Synthesis of higher alcohols Rhodium-based catalyst Syngas Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The production of sustainable aviation fuel and the shift away from fossil fuels have garnered significant attention in recent years. The aviation sector contributes to global CO2 emissions, accounting for approximately 2 % of the total in 2021 [1]. One strategy to reduce the environmental impact of the aviation sector is to use sustainable aviation fuel derived from higher alcohols. Syngas, which can be produced through biomass gasification [2], can be converted into higher alcohols. These alcohols can then undergo dehydration and oligomerization to form hydrocarbons suitable for aviation fuels. In addition to this, higher alcohols have applications as chemical intermediates and in skincare products [3]. The synthesis of higher alcohols was first identified in the 1920s when they were observed as a byproduct of the Fischer-Tropsch process. Higher alcohol synthesis is a complex reaction that produces not only alcohols but also alkanes, alkenes, methanol, and acids. Alcohols are produced via the following pathway: (1) nCO + 2 n H 2 → C n H 2 n + 1 OH + ( n − 1 ) H 2 O The water-gas shift reaction, which produces carbon dioxide, is an undesired route: (2) CO + H 2 O ⇌ H 2 + CO 2 The water-gas shift reaction can be thermodynamically limited at 250–350 °C, which is the optimal temperature for the formation of higher alcohols [4]. At higher temperatures, the water-gas shift reaction is even less thermodynamically favoured [5]. Furthermore, alkanes and alkenes are produced according to: (3) nCO + 2 n + 1 H 2 → C n H 2 n + 2 + n H 2 O (4) nCO + 2 n H 2 → C n H 2 n + n H 2 O Several heterogeneous catalysts, including Cu-based catalysts [6] and multimetallic catalysts [7,8], have been investigated for higher alcohol synthesis. Different mechanistic pathways have been proposed for formation of hydrocarbons and oxygenates. In the carbide mechanism CHx species are generated on the catalyst surface being involved in the glowing hydrocarbon chain. Insertion of CO into such fragments forming oxygenates with subsequent hydrogenation of the latter results in synthesis of higher alcohols. The challenge is thus to develop catalysts possess besides chain growth ability also a capability CO insertion and hydrogenation. For instance, copper, cobalt, gold, and rhodium have hydrogenation ability, while cobalt and iron promote chain growth [9]. Copper is selective towards the formation of methanol, methane, and higher alcohols, and by combining copper with another metal, the selectivity towards higher alcohols can be increased while the amount of methanol can be decreased [4,10]. For example, the CuCo alloy is an efficient catalyst for higher alcohol synthesis due to the balance between active sites, i.e., CO dissociation ability for chain growth and non-dissociating ability for alcohol synthesis [10,11]. While cobalt is used in the Fischer-Tropsch process, it can form carbides with a zinc-containing promoter during the reaction, which promotes the formation of higher alcohols [11]. Rhodium-based catalysts show promise for the production of C2+ oxygenates [12–21]. Manganese, when used as a promoter, is known to enhance the selectivity of C2+ oxygenates in CO hydrogenation over C-O dissociation [20]. A catalyst with a higher Mn loading of 2 wt% in RhMn supported on carbon nanotubes achieved the highest ethanol selectivity of 35 % at 4 % CO conversion at 290 °C under 20 bar using a 2:1 H2:CO ratio, compared to 1 wt% [10]. A relatively high carbon-based selectivity of C2+ alcohols of 54 % at 14 % CO conversion was obtained over a sonochemically prepared 0.8 wt% Rh on ordered mesoporous carbon catalyst at 320 °C under 30 bar using a GHSV of 120000 h−1 [20]. A supported 2 wt% Rh4(CO)12/SiO2 reduced at 350 °C yielded a 54 % selectivity to ethanol at 220 °C under 1 bar using a CO/H2 ratio of 0.59 and a space velocity of 82 h−1 [13]. In syngas transformation over Rh encapsulated in mesoporous silica, a very high selectivity to ethanol and acetaldehyde of 74.5 % was achieved under 31 bar at 270 °C using a H2/CO ratio of 2 [12]. This catalyst exhibited Rh particles of 3 nm and also contained Mnn+. For 1.1 wt% Rh on CoMn oxide, the alcohol selectivity was 41 %, calculated as CO2-free products, and the fraction of C2+OH among all alcohols was 96 % at 33 % CO conversion at 220 °C under 60 bar using a H2/CO ratio of 1.0 and 2000 ml/g/h [8]. Prior to the reaction, Rh was in the Rh3+ state, while after the reaction, the oxidation state of Rh varied between zero and one. This catalyst exhibited Co and Co2C phases after the reaction [8]. Manganese is thought to increase Rh dispersion, stabilize Rhn+, forms an interface between Rh and MnOx, and modify the electronic structure of Rh [14,22–24]. When MnOx is added to the Rh catalyst, methanol formation is typically suppressed [12]. This can be interpreted through the oxophilic character of Mn ions close to Rh enhancing CO dissociation and the reaction rate [25]. The presence of Mnn+ can tilt the adsorption mode of CO from Rh to Mn [24,25]. However, the high cost of rhodium makes its application challenging [20]. Furthermore, rhodium-based catalysts also have high activity towards the formation of acetic acid [26], which is not a desired product among jet fuel components. Acetic acid is formed from the methanol carbonylation reaction: (5) C H 3 OH + CO → C H 3 COOH The aim of this work was to investigate Rh-based bi- and multimetallic catalysts. RhMn catalyst, similar to those already reported in the literature, was prepared and compared with RhCo and RhCu materials exploring besides silica also zirconia as a support. Subsequently several Rh-based catalysts in combination with Co, MnOx and Cu have been deposited on SiO2 or ZrO2, characterized, and tested in higher alcohol synthesis. The innovative part of the work is moreover related to application of palladium in the catalyst composition. The idea behind addition of Pd, known to catalyze ketonization of carboxylic acids [27], was to investigate if acetic acid could be transformed to ketones, as acids are not desired components in fuels. Two options were explored, namely introducing palladium directly into the RhCu catalysts or alternatively using a mechanical mixture with palladium supported on zirconia. The latter option turned out to be very successful in suppression acetic acid formation. Another innovative feature of this work is related to utilization of Lewis acid sites, such as Zr in a zeolite [28] or ZrO2 per se promoting ketonization [29]. The main parameters studied were the effect of temperature and catalyst stability. The catalysts were characterized by several physical and chemical methods, such as nitrogen physisorption, elemental analysis, morphology by SEM-EDX and TEM, identification of phases and metal particle size by XRD, SEM-EDX, TEM, oxidation state of metals by XPS, reducibility of metals by TPR, quantification of carbonaceous materials by CHNS and TGA. The most important issue was to establish a relationship between the catalyst structure and performance. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Chemicals The chemicals used in this work are shown in Table S1. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis The objective of this study was to investigate the impact of metal and support on high alcohol synthesis. To this end, the following catalysts were synthesized and utilized: 1Rh5Co/ZrO2, 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2, 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2, and 2 Pd/ZrO2. These catalysts were prepared using commercial ZrO2 from Alfa Aesar (J14W004, no. 43815). Additionally, 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 was prepared using silica gel from Sigma Aldrich (Davisil Grade 62) as a support. The index in the catalyst code corresponds to the nominal metal loading. For instance, 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 signifies 1 wt% Rh and 5 wt% Co on zirconia. Prior to synthesis, the zirconia and silica were dried overnight at 109 ºC and subsequently cooled in a desiccator to prevent moisture absorption. The catalysts were synthesized using the incipient wetness co-impregnation method. The required quantities of the respective precursors were dissolved in distilled water. These precursors included rhodium chloride RhCl3*4 H2O (OJSC Aurat, 36.68 % Rh content), manganese nitrate Mn(NO3)2*6 H2O (OJSC Reachem), cobalt nitrate Co(NO3)2*6 H2O (OJSC Reachem), copper nitrate Cu(NO3)2*3 H2O (OJSC Reachem), and palladium chloride PdCl2 (OJSC Reachem). Aqueous solutions of RhCl3 (0.5 M) and H2PdCl4 (1 M) were prepared for a more precise introduction of noble metals. Samples of Co, Cu, and Mn salts were weighed and dissolved in approximately 3 ml of distilled water to prepare the corresponding aqueous mixture for impregnating 1 g of support. Following impregnation, all catalysts were dried overnight at 109 ºC. Subsequently, Rh-containing catalysts were calcined at 450 ºC for 6 h with a temperature ramp of 2 ºC/min, while the Pd/ZrO2 catalyst was reduced at 270 ºC for 3 h with a temperature ramp of 2 ºC/min. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The morphology and elemental composition of both fresh and spent catalysts were determined using a Leo Gemini 1530 microscope. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging was conducted on fresh catalysts utilizing a Themis Z electron microscope (Thermo Fisher Scientific), with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV and a limiting resolution of 0.07 nm. The samples were positioned on a carbon support attached to a copper grid. TEM images were captured using a Ceta 16 CCD matrix, in conjunction with a SuperX energy dispersive X-ray detector (both Thermo Fisher Scientific) for bulk elemental analysis. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-EDX) was employed, and TEM was integrated with elemental analysis (HRTEM-STEM, and mapping). X-Ray diffraction patterns of the freshly reduced and spent catalysts were obtained using a STOE STADI MP instrument equipped with a MYTHEN2 1 K detector in transmission mode, applying MoKα radiation (λ = 0.7093 Å). Measurements were conducted by scanning in the range of 4–32° with a step size of 0.015º in 2ϴ. Phase identification was performed using the ICDD PDF-2 database (International Centre for Diffraction Data, 2009), and the Scherrer equation was utilized to calculate the average crystalline sizes of the phases. The textural properties of the fresh and spent catalysts were analyzed using a Micrometrics 3Flex instrument. Prior to the measurements, the catalyst samples were outgassed at 180 °C for a minimum of 1 h. Following drying, the catalysts were weighed and then placed into the analysis instrument to be dried at 250 °C for 4 h under vacuum conditions. For each measurement, the sample size was approximately 0.1 g. Nitrogen adsorption was conducted at −196 °C. The surface areas were calculated using the Dubinin-Radushkevich and BET methods within the p/p0 range of 0.1–0.4. The pore size distribution was determined using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method, employing a molar volume VL = 35.68*10−6 m3/mol. X-Ray photoelectron spectra were recorded using a Thermoscientific Nexsa instrument equipped with AlKα radiation. The XPS analysis was conducted under vacuum conditions, and the survey spectra were recorded between 0 and 1100 eV while applying a 200 eV pass energy. The X-Ray spot size was 400 µm. The XPS results were compared to the literature and Thermofisher.com XPS graphs. All XPS graphs were corrected with a shift based on the supporting material, which was approximately 0.3–1 eV. The temperature-programmed reduction was analyzed using a Micrometrics Autochem 2910 instrument. The sample was initially dried using a temperature program of 10 ºC/min to 120 ºC under an argon flow of 20 ml/min, after which the sample was cooled back down to ambient temperature. For the measurement, a gas mixture ratio of 9:1 argon to hydrogen was used, corresponding to an argon and hydrogen flow rate of 18 ml/min and 2 ml/min, respectively. During the measurement, the temperature was increased at a rate of 10 ºC/min to 700 °C. The acidity of the catalyst was determined using a Belcat II Microtrac MBR instrument. The catalyst (200 mg) was pre-treated at 500 °C under a helium flow of 30 ml/min for 1 h, after which it was cooled down to 100 °C. Ammonia (5 vol% NH3/He) was adsorbed for 30 min, and the physisorbed ammonia was desorbed over a 30-minute period before the sample was cooled to 50 °C. The measurement was conducted using a temperature program of 50 °C to 600 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. CO DRIFTS measurements were conducted utilizing a Shimadzu IRTracer-100 spectrometer, outfitted with a high-temperature environmental chamber and a DRIFTS collector from Spectra-Tech Inc. The water-cooled cell was connected to gas lines for N2, H2, and CO. The experimental procedure involved placing a small quantity of catalyst powder in the cell's sample holder. Subsequently, the cell lid was secured, and a brief N2 flush initiated the cooling of the cell wall. The catalyst sample underwent reduction at 300 °C, facilitated by a 10 ml/min flow of hydrogen (Woikoski, N50) over a duration of 30 min. Post-reduction, the cell was purged with a 10 ml/min flow of nitrogen (Woikoski, N50) prior to cooling to the target temperature. A background spectrum was acquired at either ambient temperature or 275 °C, following which the gas composition was altered to include 10 % CO (Air Liquide, 3.7) in nitrogen, maintaining the same 10 ml/min flow. The catalyst surface was saturated with CO for 15 min, after which the CO flow was terminated. The spectrum was immediately recorded at the 0-minute mark, and subsequently at 5, 10, 20, and 30 min. The spent catalysts underwent organic elemental analysis using a Thermo Scientific Flash 2000 combustion analyzer, operating at 1000 ºC in an oxygen-rich environment. The quantities of C, H, N, and S were calibrated using cystine, methionine, sulphanilamide, and 2,5-bis(5-tert-butyl-benzoxazol-2-yl)thiophene as reference standards. Thermal gravimetric analysis was executed on a TA Instruments Discovery SDT 650, with a temperature range from room temperature to 800 °C and a heating rate of 10 °C/ min under both air and nitrogen flow. An alumina pan with a capacity of 90 µl was employed, and the sample mass ranged from 10 to 35 mg. 2.4 Catalytic tests 2.4.1 Reactor set-up The experimental procedures were conducted in a packed bed column reactor with dimensions of length 30 cm, volume 8.5 ml, internal diameter 0.6 cm. The materials utilized typically included 0.5 g of the catalyst, quartz sand, glass beads, and quartz wool. The catalyst particles employed were within the size range of 125 – 225 µm. The experimental conditions were maintained at a high pressure of 30 bar, within a temperature range of 225–300 °C, and each temperature was sustained for a duration of 24 h. During the catalyst testing phase, a liquid sample was extracted, weighed, and analyzed every 24 h, provided liquid formation was observed. The experiments were conducted at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 2000 ml/(g(catalyst) h), inclusive of 6 % nitrogen serving as an internal standard. The ratio of hydrogen to carbon monoxide H 2 CO was maintained at either 1 or 2. 2.4.2 Pre-treatment of the catalyst before the experiment The catalyst underwent a pre-treatment process, which encompassed both reduction and carburization, conducted at a temperature of 300 °C. The reduction phase involved the catalyst being subjected to a flow of hydrogen at a rate of 10 ml/min for a duration of 6 h. Subsequently, the reactor was purged with nitrogen gas for 15 min at a flow rate of 10 ml/min. The final stage of the pre-treatment involved carburizing the catalyst with carbon monoxide for 6 h at a flow rate of 10 ml/min. Following the completion of the pre-treatment, the reactor was flushed with nitrogen gas for an overnight period at a temperature of 225 °C. 2.4.3 Product analysis The gaseous products were analyzed using an HP 6890 series gas chromatograph (GC), equipped with an HP-PLOT Q column (30 m length, 40 µm film thickness) for the separation of CO, CO2, and alkanes. Additionally, an HP-PLOT Molesive column (30 m length, 25 µm film thickness) was used for the resolution of oxygen, nitrogen, carbon monoxide, and methane. Helium served as the carrier gas in the GC. The retention times of the calibrated gaseous compounds are documented in Table S2. The liquid products were examined using an HP 6890 series GC system, utilizing a DB-FFAP column (60 m length, 250 µm diameter, 0.25 µm film thickness). The temperature program applied was as follows: 50 °C for 2 min, followed by a ramp of 5 °C/min to 220 °C, which was held for 10 min. The inlet and detector temperatures were set at 200 °C and 250 °C, respectively, with a split ratio of 20:1. Helium was employed as the carrier gas. The calibrated liquid products and their retention times are presented in Table S3. Unidentified liquid products were analyzed using gas chromatography coupled with a mass spectrometer (6890 Series GC system combined with a Mass Selective Detector 5973 network, both from Agilent Technologies). This system was used to identify unknown compounds in several liquid samples. The GC utilized a DB-1 column (30 m length, 0.25 mm inner diameter, 0.5 µm film thickness). Helium was used as the carrier gas, with a split ratio of 40:1, and the temperature setpoint was 280 °C. The initial oven temperature was set at 40 °C with a holding time of 2 min, followed by a temperature increase to 250 °C at a ramp of 10 °C/min, held for 3 min. The water content in the liquid phase samples was determined by Karl Fisher titration using a Metrohm 736 GP Titrino instrument. Hydranal dry methanol was used as the reactant, and hydranal composite served as the titration agent. Prior to the measurements, calibration was performed with 10 µl of water two or three times. Measurements proceeded when the difference between two calibration values was less than ± 0.2 ml. For each measurement, 10 µl of the liquid product was injected into hydranal dry methanol. 2.5 Definitions Conversion of CO and hydrogen are calculated from: (6) X CO , i = 1 − V ̇ CO , i V ̇ CO , 0 Where V ̇ CO , 0 is the flow of CO entering the reactor and V ̇ CO , I is the calculated flow of eluted CO. Carbon based product selectivity was calculated from: (12) S n , alcohol = n . c n ∑ n . c n Where n is the number of carbons in the alcohol and c n is the concentration of n -alcohol. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization results 3.1.1 SEM-EDX results Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) images of both the fresh and spent catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 and Supplementary Figures S1-S3. The fresh and spent 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 catalysts exhibited average particle sizes ranging from 125 to 250 µm and 150–300 µm, respectively (Fig. 1. e, f). Residues of quartz wool (SiO2) were discernible in the images of the spent catalysts. Notably, the spent 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 catalyst showed signs of decomposition, with fresh particles varying in size from 22 to 88 µm, while the spent particles were significantly smaller, measuring less than 10 µm. The fresh 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 catalyst had particle sizes ranging from 10 to 60 µm. However, during the reaction, agglomeration of the catalyst particles occurred, resulting in agglomerated particles reaching lengths of up to 500 µm (Fig. S1). In contrast, the spent 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited less agglomeration compared to 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2, although some large agglomerates measuring 250 µm in length were still present (Fig. S1b). Similarly, the spent 1Rh5CuPd/ZrO2 particles also agglomerated during the reaction (Fig. S2). The SEM images of the spent 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 catalyst also revealed particle agglomeration during the reaction (Fig. S2). The particles in the 2 Pd/ZrO2 catalyst were relatively small (Fig. S3). The chemical compositions of the fresh catalysts are detailed in Table S4. For the 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 catalyst, the quantities of Co and Zr, reflecting more the surface composition, increased in the spent catalyst, while the Rh content decreased, a trend similar to that observed for RhCu/ZrO2. Conversely, for 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2, these ratios remained constant, while the Rh/Pd ratio changed during the reaction. The oxygen content in 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 decreased by 16 % compared to the fresh catalyst, while for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2, the decrease was only 7 %. In contrast, the oxygen content in 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 increased. These observations suggest that a reduction of metal oxides occurred in 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Co/ZrO2. The increase in oxygen content can be attributed to its high coking ability and the accumulation of oxygen on the catalyst surface (refer to CHNS results in Table S11). The carbon content in the spent catalysts decreased in the following sequence: 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 > 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 > 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2. This trend aligns with the values obtained from the CHNS analysis. It is likely that the CHNS analysis provides a more reliable measure of carbon content compared to SEM-EDX, given the use of carbonaceous tape in the latter method. 3.1.2 TEM results Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) images and elemental analyses for various catalysts are presented in Fig. 2. The monoclinic zirconia phase is distinctly visible in Fig. 2a. Comparable images for m-ZrO2 have been reported in other studies [31], and these findings are corroborated by the results of the X-ray Diffraction (XRD) analysis (refer to Section 3.1.4 for XRD results). Metal particle size distribution 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 is shown in Fig. 2e. The average metal particle size range is 1.7 nm. Additionally, Rh clusters are discernible in the TEM-Energy Dispersive X-ray (EDX) image of 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 (Fig. 2. c). It is noteworthy that no Rh species were detected in the XRD for both fresh and spent 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2, suggesting that their size was small. The MnOx phase was not well-dispersed in 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 (Fig. 2d). Elemental mapping of 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 reveals that the active sites are more clustered compared to the other catalysts analyzed (Fig. 2d). TEM-EDX images of 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2, presented in Fig. S4 and S5, illustrate that the metals are highly dispersed in both of these catalysts. The elemental mass fractions determined by TEM-EDX analysis exhibited some discrepancies when compared to SEM-EDX analysis (refer to Tables S4 and S5). Notably, the content of Cu and Co in 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 was overestimated by the TEM-EDX method. Lattice fringes from different catalysts determined from TEM images are presented in Table S6 as well as Fig. 2 and Fig. S6. It should be noted that TEM images of the fresh and spent catalysts might not reveal the nature of catalytically active sites with TEM being an ex-situ method. The elemental mapping in any case demonstrates very homogeneous distribution of the metals in the catalysts with an intimate contact between them. This allows to conclude that Rh is enriched with e.g. Co and the same is valid for other zirconia-based catalysts. 3.1.3 Nitrogen physisorption Textural properties of the fresh and spent catalysts are summarized in Table 1 and Fig. 3 and Fig. S7. The results show that silica supported catalyst exhibited much higher surface area in comparison to ZrO2 supported ones. This monoclinic zirconia exhibited a slightly higher surface area in comparison to conventional zirconia with surface area in the range of 30–50 m2/g [32]. In the current case the surface area and average pore size of 67 m2/g and 7.4 nm, respectively, while manufacturer reported surface area and median pore size of 103 m2/g and 20.2 nm, respectively. The largest decrease of surface area after the reaction was observed in 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 catalyst followed by 1Rh5Co/ZrO2. A large decreased in the surface area in the spent 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 material can be explained by the presence of very large agglomerated particles in SEM image (Fig. S1b). 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited also high acidity (see below), which can partially explain extensive its coking. This catalyst exhibited also the smallest surface area in the fresh catalyst. The percentage of the retained pore volume in the spent catalyst decreased as follows: 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 > 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 >1Rh5Co/ZrO2> 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2. Interestingly, the highest retained pore volume was found in 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2, however, this catalyst formed very large agglomerates containing pores, but the active sites in this catalyst were not accessible (see Section 3.1.1). The average pore sizes for fresh and spent 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 catalyst were 15 nm, which is also reported by the manufacturer for silica gel, while for other catalysts it was ca. 3.5 −4 nm (Fig. 3b, c), thus no large change in the average pore size was observed. All catalysts were mesoporous exhibiting the hysteresis loop and ca. 10 % of the pores were microporous. It can be seen from Fig. 3b that the average pore diameter for 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 was nearly double in comparison to those of other catalysts. Furthermore, the pore volume for the smaller pores in the range of 4–7 nm decreased more for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 in comparison to other catalysts. However, the largest decrease of the pore volume was observed for 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2. 3.1.4 XRD results XRD results of 1Rh1.52MnOxSiO2 showed that the fresh catalyst exhibited low crystallinity ( Fig. 4a). The wide halo in the region of 2ϴ = 5–15⁰ is due to the presence of X-ray amorphous material SiO2. Broadening peaks with low intensity can be attributed to the manganese oxide MnO phase (PDF # 000–007–0230, space group Fm-3 m, a=b=c=4.445 Å). Due to high Rh dispersion and its low loading no metallic nor oxidic Rh peaks were detected. XRD pattern of the freshly reduced 1Rh 5Co/ZrO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 5a. All reflexes are related to monoclinic zirconia ZrO2 (m-ZrO2, PDF # 00–037–1484) with average CSD D(ZrO2)=10.5 nm. No other crystallographic phases are detected. XRD pattern of the spent 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 5b. Some reflexes are related to monoclinic zirconia ZrO2 (m-ZrO2, PDF # 00–037–1484) with average CSD D(ZrO2)=10.5 nm. In addition, the pattern contains reflexes characteristic for Co0 metal phase with hexagonal closed-packed structure (PDF №00–005–0727, P63/mmc, a=b=2.503 Å, c=4.060 Å, γ=120⁰). However, the determined values of the crystal lattice parameter a=b=2.537 Å, c=4.106 Å are much higher than that for metallic cobalt phase Co0. Probably metal cobalt Co0 is doped with Rh atoms forming a substitutional solid solution. The database of inorganic compounds (ICSD) contains some data for a solid solution of composition Co0.8Rh0.2 of hexagonal structure with unit cell parameters a=b=2.555 Å, c=4.119 Å. The CSD of the determined metal phase D is ca.5 nm. The XRD pattern of freshly reduced 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 showed no other crystallized phases than monoclinic zirconia with the scattering domain (CSD) for this catalyst of 10.5 nm (Fig. S8a). The peaks for metal phases were not clearly visible in XRD due to their small size, and amount, and high metal dispersion. As a comparison, rhodium could not be detected with 1.1 % loading in [8]. On the other hand, in the spent catalyst samples the active metals could be detected (Fig. S8b). It was also interesting to observe, that the lattice patterns of RhCo, RhCu, and RhCuPd were significantly bigger compared to the database which indicates formation of intermetallic compounds. XRD pattern of the spent 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. S8b. It contains reflexes from monoclinic zirconia ZrO2 (m-ZrO2, PDF # 00–037–1484). The crystal parameters coincide with the standard values within the error of determination. The average coherently scattering domain (CSD) D(ZrO2) is 10.5 nm. In addition, the sample contains a metallic copper phase Cu0 (PDF # 004–0836, space group Fm-3 m, a=b=c=3.615 Å). The determined value of the lattice parameter a=b=c=3.621(2) Å is slightly higher compared to the standard value. Average CSD of Cu° for this catalyst is 10.0 nm. Narrow intensive reflexes can be referred to the SiO2 quartz phase (PDF#00–046–1045) with CSD of SiO2 D(SiO2) exceeding 100 nm. XRD pattern of the freshly reduced 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. S9a. All reflexes are related to monoclinic zirconia ZrO2 (m-ZrO2, PDF # 00–037–1484, space symmetry group Р21/с, a=5.147 Å b=5.213 Å c=5.315 Å, β=99.2°). The crystal parameters coincide with the standard values within the error of determination. The average coherently scattering domain of ZrO2 was 10.5 nm. No other crystallized phases were detected by XRD. XRD pattern of the spent 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. S9b. Some reflexes can be related to monoclinic zirconia ZrO2 (m-ZrO2, PDF # 00–037–1484) with average CSD D(ZrO2)=10.5 nm. In addition, the sample contains a metal phase with fcc structure. However, the value of the crystal lattice parameter a=3.642 Å is much higher than that characteristic of the metallic copper phase Cu0 (PDF # 004–0836, a= 3.615 Å). Probably the increase of the lattice parameter is due to doping of metallic copper Cu0 with Pd and/or Rh atoms resulting in a solid solution of substitution. Thus, the values of the lattice parameter of the isostructural phases Pd0 (PDF # 00–046–1043) and Rh0 (PDF # 00–005–0685) are much higher than those of the Cu0 phase and are a=3.890 Å and a=3.803 Å, respectively. The CSD of the metal phase is D=6.5 nm. When comparing this particle size with the one for 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 with 10.0 nm (see above) it can be seen that the presence of Pd was able to retard sintering of metal particles. The increase in the lattice parameter might be due to doping with Rh and Pd atoms which formed an intermetallic solid solution. Rhodium and palladium exhibited also larger lattice parameter values, corresponding to a=3.890 Å and a=3.803 Å, respectively. The metal phases were in a facial-centered-cubic structure. As a conclusion from XRD measurements it can be stated that the average metal particle size increased as follows 1Rh5MnOx/SiO2 (< 3 nm) < 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 (5 nm) < 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 (6.5 nm) < 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 (10 nm). 3.1.5 NH3-TPD results Acidity of ZrO2, 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2, and 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 catalysts was determined by ammonia TPD in a temperature range from 50 to 625 ºC ( Fig. 6, Table S7). Ammonia is desorbed in the temperature range of 140–490 °C analogously to [33]. It was also stated that typically monoclinic ZrO2 exhibits high concentration of medium acid sites desorbing ammonia in the temperature range of 280–300 °C analogously to the current case for monoclinic ZrO2 confirmed by XRD. On the other hand, a high intensity NH3 desorption peak is observed in 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 at 325 ºC. This shows that addition of Rh and Co increases acidity slightly compared to the parent ZrO2 (Table S7). Ammonia TPD gave signal originating both from Lewis and Brønsted acid sites and it is known that metal oxides exhibit also Lewis acidity. High acidity for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 is due to a relatively high loading of cobalt, as Con+ ions are known to exhibit Lewis acidity [34]. 3.1.6 XPS results The XPS results for different Rh catalysts are shown in Figs. 7, 8 and S10. XPS results for freshly reduced 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2, 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 demonstrate that rhodium was in oxide form (Figs. 7, 8, S10), while in the spent it was close to the binding energy of the metallic form. The lowest Rh binding energy in the spent catalyst was observed in 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 ( Table 2). It can be seen that MnO2 is reduced during the reaction to MnO phase (Fig. 7d), however, if the Rh and MnOx phase form a mixed Rh and Mn oxide phase, the complete MnO reduction can be inhibited [35]. MnO satellite peaks are found in the spent catalyst [36] which was also observed in the current case close to ∼647 eV (Fig. 7d). Furthermore, it should be noted that this satellite peak is not present for either Mn2O3 or MnO2 [37]. High O1 s peak was found in the fresh 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 catalyst which is related to the C-O bond according to [38]. XPS results from fresh 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 showed that rhodium in Rh3d3/2 signal was in oxidic state (Fig. 8a), while after the reaction it was slightly reduced giving a peak at 307.5 eV close to Rh+ (Fig. 8a,b) [39]. Cobalt has a strong satellite peak at higher BE values [40] indicating that it is in CoO form both in the fresh and spent catalysts (Fig. 8e, f). In spent 1Rh5Co/ZrO2, metal oxides were transformed to metal hydroxide [41]. For the fresh 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 Cu2p peak at 933.5 eV (Fig. S10) which is related to CuO on ZrO2 [44]. In addition the peaks at 944 eV and 953.2 eV are satellite peaks for Cu2+ [45]. O 1 s peak at 530.3 eV is close to that reported for ZrO2 at 530.1 eV in [46]. Metal carbonate was formed during the catalyst testing in 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 catalysts analogously as in 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 spent catalyst in line with FTIR catalysis (see below). For O1s in the spent 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 peak at 531.5 eV is in line with O 1 s peak at 531.5 eV corresponding to CuCO3 [47]. Additionally, one peak in O 1 s spectrum is visible at 532.8 eV. 3.1.7 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) results Temperature programmed reduction results showed that all the catalysts were reduced below 300 °C (Fig. S11) and the highest reduction degree was obtained for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 followed 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 and 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 while 2 Pd/ZrO2 exhibited the lowest degree of reduction (Table S8). Manganese oxide is reduced in Mn/SiO2 catalyst at ca. 377 °C [35] while in the current case no peak at this temperature was observed for 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 indicating that MnOx is not reduced. On the other hand, β-MnO2 reduced more easily than γ-MnO2 followed by β-MnO2 with the peak maximum at 240 °C, 254 °C and 274 °C, respectively [48]. According to XPS MnO2 is reduced during the reaction to MnO. The second peak in TPR disappeared at 220 °C indicating that MnOx was not reduced during TPR experiment. The two first reduction peaks for 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2, 1Rh5Co/ZrO2, and 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 can be explained by the reduction of Rh2O3 [49]. Similarly, the XPS results confirmed that rhodium was reduced to its metallic form before experiments. These catalysts formed also intermetallic solid solutions based on XRD measurements. Furthermore, rhodium might be reduced together with cobalt which shows a lower reduction temperature. The reduction of Co on ZrO2 occurred at 274 °C (Co3O4 -> CoO) and a peak at 341 °C corresponded to reduction of CoO to Co [49]. In the current case the reduction at T3 occurred at 223 °C, which is too low for reduction of cobalt species. It should also be noted that although, the total reducible metal content in 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 is essentially the same as for 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 being 5.51 wt% and 5.63 wt% (Table S4), respectively, the hydrogen uptake for the former catalyst is higher. The second maximum for 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 at 169 °C is close to that reported in [24] for 1 wt%Rh-1 wt%Mn/SiO2 at 182 °C, while in [24] no low temperature peak for Rh reduction was observed. Most probably the Rh-Mn interactions were stronger than in the current work. While the XPS results confirmed the oxidic form of the catalysts, palladium (Pd3d) and zirconium (Zr3p) were overlapping in the XPS graphs. Palladium was considered in the metallic form in line with the preparation of the palladium catalyst. This corresponds well to a low H2 uptake value, as for the oxidized form, the theoretical value would be 375.9 µmol H2/gcatalyst. In CO DRIFTS measurements for 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 the peak at 2065 cm−1 related to CO adsorption on Rh0 [51,52] was very high at 25 °C ( Fig. 9a), however, the corresponding symmetric and antisymmetric carbonyl stretching of gemdicarbonyl Rh(l)/CO2 (CO(gdc)) are also clearly visible at 2097 and 2031 cm−1, respectively for this catalyst (Table S9). These are close to those reported in [53]. It should be noted that CO(l) position normally found in the range of 2030–2060 cm−1 [54] was shifted to a lower wavenumber at 275 °C (Table S10). This could be originated from a carbonyl hydride species [H-Rh-CO] located on Rh0 [50]. As a comparison to ref. [54] it can be noted that the best catalyst in that study, Rh(1.5)-La(2.6) exhibited analogous patterns as observed for 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2, which was selective towards alcohols (see Section 3.2.2). Analogously to [51], the gemdicarbonyl peaks disappeared when the DRIFTs measurement was performed at 275 °C in the current work, while analogous result was obtained at 230 °C in [54,55] and at 270 °C in [51]. It was also reported in [51] that a small broad peak close to 1716 cm−1 is related to tilted CO species on Rh-Mn interface, however, in the current case this was not clearly evident. For 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 the peak at 2066 cm−1 measured at 25 °C corresponding to linearly adsorbed CO, (CO(l)) is very small (Fig. 9b). On the other hand, the peaks at 2094 cm−1 and 2019 cm−1 corresponding to Rh+(CO)2 are clearly visible at room temperature, while at 275 °C a peak was initially found at 2060 cm−1 and after 30 min a peak at 2034 cm−1 became visible corresponding to linearly adsorbed CO. It was stated in [56] that the peak at 2060 cm−1 in Co/SiO2 is related to Co(0001) active for FT process. In the XPS results for spent 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 the oxidation state of Co is slightly lower than that for Co2+ indicating that it is partially in metallic state. The band at 1362 cm−1 in [54] was assigned to formate species, while HCO3 - species were also suggested to have an absorption band at 1360 cm−1. It is also possible that in the current case Coδ+ gives a peak close to 2039 cm−1 according to analogous results reported in [57] (Table S10) and cobalt is not fully reduced according to the XPS even after the experiments. The peak at 1520 cm−1 is assigned to monodentate carbonate species in agreement with XPS. 3.1.8 Organic elemental analysis (CHNS) results The organic elemental analysis was done three times for each catalyst. The average values are displayed in Table S11. No traces of sulfur or nitrogen were detected in the spent catalysts. A high amount of accumulated carbon was observed in 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 which exhibited the highest acidity (Table S7). Although 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 is the least acidic of these catalysts due to neutral support material, it contained the second highest carbon content. However, for this catalyst the H/C ratio is higher than for the ZrO2-supported catalysts indicating accumulation of alkanes, while for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 it is below 2 subsequently the coke due to the presence of more unsaturated organic compounds. 3.1.9 TGA results The results from thermogravimetric analysis are shown in Fig. S12 and Table 3. The first peak, close to 100 ºC indicates water evaporation. The weight decrease from three different spent catalysts showed that the largest weight loss above 100 °C was detected for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 followed by 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2, while 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 exhibited the lowest amount of carbonaceous materials. The first peak was between 50 and 125 ºC, the second peak was between 225 and 300 ºC, and the final peak was between 415 and 500 ºC. 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2, being less acidic, produces more coke which can be seen with the 3rd peak. However, it cannot be ruled out that a high H content in 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 can originate from a high amount of hydroxyl groups on SiO2 [58]. 3.2 Catalyst performance results 3.2.1 Reaction rates, conversion and time on stream behaviour The highest rate for CO transformation was observed at 270 °C for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 (0.091 mmol/gcat.s) followed by 1Rh1.52MnOxSiO2 (0.0022 mmol/(gcat.s)), while the rates for 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 were very low. For the most active catalyst the degree of metal reduction was quite high (Table S8). This catalyst contained initially Rh in oxide form, while it was reduced to metallic species. Furthermore, no metallic Rh was observed in the spent catalyst indicating that this catalyst retained its small average metal particle size. The second most active catalyst was 1Rh5Co/ZrO2, which exhibited also the highest acidity and small metal oxide particles not visible in XRD measurements. After the reaction metallic species of Co or Rh or possibly a solid solution Co0.8Rh0.2 were observed in XRD pattern. The particle size could not be determined by XRD because of low intensity. The reaction rates are not correlating with the degree of metal reduction. For example, 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 unexpectedly exhibited a low rate despite a high degree of metal reduction. For this catalyst, severe agglomeration occurred, as was observed in SEM images (Fig. S1b). Furthermore, XRD measurements revealed that metallic copper exhibited the largest metal particle size of 10 nm after the experiment, which also can explain its low activity. The most active catalyst with respect to CO conversion was 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 followed by the mixture of 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2+2 Pd/ZrO2, while 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 gave a slightly lower conversion without Pd/ZrO2. (Table 6, Fig. 10). On the other hand, 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 were the least active (Fig. S13). The activation energies were calculated with the Arrhenius equation from the reacted CO for all catalysts in the temperature range of 225–275 °C ( Table 5), while at 300 °C mass transfer limitations occur ( Fig. 11) visible by changes in the slope. The results showed 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 exhibited much lower activation energy in comparison to 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 and 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 + 2 Pd/ZrO2. The two former catalysts exhibited also a higher degree of metal reduction, which considering higher activity of the metal compared to oxides, can explain their lower activation energy. As a comparison with the results reported in [16] with the EA= 105 – 113 kJ/mol for Rh/SiO2, Rh-La/SiO2, and Rh-V/SiO2 were more active due to high Rh dispersion. The activation energy for RhCoxO3/SiO2 was reported to be 85.3 kJ/mol in the temperature range of 370–300 °C under 3 MPa [53] being close to the current activation energies for ZrO2 supported catalysts. Time-on stream behavior for each catalyst shows that a decline in CO conversion (%/min) at 300 °C was the highest for 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 (2.5 %/min) ( Fig. 12a) followed by 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 (1.18 %/min) > RhMnOx/SiO2+Pd/ZrO2 (0.54 %/min). Such activity sequence was not correlating with catalyst acidity, i.e. the highest acidity was determined for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2. On the other hand, the highest amount of carbonaceous components was accumulating on1Rh5Co/ZrO2, which exhibited a much smaller average pore size in comparison to 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 (Fig. 3). For 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 no reactions occurred below 225 °C. Catalyst deactivation rate calculated from CO conversion increased with increasing conversion from 0.07 %/h at 250 °C to 0.20 %/h at 275 °C followed by 2.5 %/h at 300 °C. As a comparison, CO conversion in syngas transformation at 270 °C under 30 bar using H2:CO:N2 ratio of 6:3:1 increased during the first 3 h being thereafter stable for 17 h TOS [22]. When comparing the catalyst properties, it can be observed that the weight ratio Rh to Mn was 3.75 in [22] while in the current case it was only 0.75 (Table S4), which might be the reason for more rapid deactivation of the latter catalyst. However, in the presence of more Mn the catalyst was more selective towards longer alcohols (see below). It can be concluded that despite of coking, 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 retained its activity due to its large average pore size and absence of noticeable sintering based on XRD. 3.2.2 Product distribution Overall, the product distribution shows that 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 gave high amounts of light alkanes and also CO2 at 300 °C (Fig. 12 f) formed via the water gas shift reaction while its carbon based liquid selectivity was low. The metal particle size after the reaction was 5 nm based on XRD and the metal oxides were not present [22]. It has been reported in [6] that CO2 selectivity increased with increasing Cu particle size over K-Cu-Fe/CNF in syngas transformations. However, at 275 °C over 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 only 3.6 % CO2 was formed most probably due to less sintering occurring at a lower temperature. In comparison 0.7 % carbon based CO2 selectivity was reported over 1.5Rh-0.4 Mn at 270 °C under 30 bar [22]. For 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 especially alkane selectivity was enhanced with increasing temperature and time-on-stream (Fig. 12b). At the same time selectivity to alkenes with this catalyst decreased. Thus alkane selectivity increased due to absence of sintering observed by XRD and reduction of ionic Rh to metallic one. Production of the liquids was observed over 1Rh152MnOx/SiO2 + 2 Pd/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 already at 250 °C, while 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 started to generate liquid products at 275 °C (Table 4). The largest liquid production per hour was observed for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2, which was not, however, very selective towards alcohol formation. 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2+2 Pd/ZrO2 was more selective to the liquid phase products at lower temperature than 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2. This can be due to the lowest temperature for hydrogen consumption during TPR detected for 2 Pd/ZrO2 (Table S8), which might give more complete metal reduction facilitating faster reaction. When comparing the performance of 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 with that of 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 (Table 4), it can be observed that at 300 °C much higher selectivity to alkanes was obtained with the former catalyst. It should also be pointed out that these results are not fully comparative because of different conversion levels. Moreover, structure sensitivity can play a role. Precise elucidation of the impact of the cluster size is not straightforward, as according to TEM Rh is highly dispersed in the fresh catalysts, and the size of metal clusters could be reliably determined only for 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2. Interestingly, 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 after the reaction exhibited a larger Rh particle size, 5 nm based on XRD results (Section 3.1.4), than Rh in 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2, for which no metallic particles could be observed by XRD. This result might indicate structure sensitivity [59], i.e. larger metal particles with more terrace sites in 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 promote formation of long chain alkanes, as also observed in the higher β values for this catalyst in comparison to 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 (see below). Detailed results of the product distribution over different catalysts are given below. 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 and 1Rh5Cu1Pd/ZrO2 catalysts did not generate any liquid products (Table 4, Fig. S11b, d). No liquid products were formed with all other catalysts except 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2+2 Pd/ZrO2 at 225°C (Table 4), which were not very active in syngas transformation. Low activity of 1Rh5Cu/ZrO2 is partially explained by metal sintering and agglomeration of catalyst particles occurring during the reaction. The water content of all the liquid samples varied between 71 % and 90 % (Table S12). The carbon-based selectivity to alkanes, alkenes and alcohols and acids for different catalysts is depicted in Figs. 13–15. 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 gave high selectivity of methane which increased with elevation of CO conversion and temperature (Fig. 13a), in accordance with thermodynamics. On the other hand, formation of C2+ alkanes over this catalyst was very limited. Interestingly, 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 gave also ethene, propene and butene. Formation of liquid oxygenates was limited over this catalyst below 275 °C (Fig. 13c). Substantial amounts of ethanol and acetic acid were also formed over this catalyst, namely acetic acid selectivity of 48 % and 35 % was obtained at 275 °C and 300 °C, respectively (Fig. 14c). Rhn+ is known to promote C2-oxygenates [60] and unpromoted rhodium generated acetic acid from CO and H2 in the temperature range of 210–270 °C [60]. In the current case the ratio between ethanol to acetic acid selectivity was 0.42 at 275 °C, increasing to 0.72 at 300 °C. This result is in accordance with [22] when less acetic acid was formed at a higher temperature due to enhanced hydrogenation of OH* leading to formation of water. The latter reaction is competing with the insertion of OH* species into CH3CO*, eventually leading to acetic acid. A mixture of 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2+Pd/ZrO2 gave slightly higher CO conversion and ca. the same selectivity to alkanes as the catalyst without Pd/ZrO2, however, the selectivity to alkenes was low due to the high hydrogenation ability of Pd. The unfavored CO2 formation was also promoted over the latter catalyst. Furthermore, the presence of Pd decreased nearly 10-fold the selectivity to acetic acid (Fig. 14), which could be expected because Pd catalyzes ketonization of acids [27]. The product mixtures obtained over 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 and 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 +Pd/ZrO2 at 275 °C and 300 °C, respectively were analyzed by GC-MS. The results (Fig. S15, S16) demonstrated that the former catalyst produced mainly acetic acid and a smaller amount of butyric acid. Other predominant compounds were ethyl acetate and propanoic acid. In addition, small amounts of alcohols, butyl acetate and pentanoic acid were also confirmed in the reaction mixture. On the other hand, in the case of 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 +Pd/ZrO2 the intensity of acetic acid peak decreased and at the same time relatively large peaks of 1-butanol, 2-pentanone, 2-methyl-1-butanol, 1-pentanol and 4-methyl-1-pentanol and 2-heptanone were observed. These results clearly show that the amounts of carboxylic acids can be decreased when a mixture of Pd/ZrO2 and 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 was used as a catalyst. In addition, several ketones and alcohols were formed in the presence of 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 +Pd/ZrO2. This result is in accordance with the literature [62], reporting for example formation of C5-C10 ketones at 400 °C from acetic and decanoic acids mixture over Pd-doped CeO2/Al2O3 catalyst. The obvious benefit for ketonization in syngas transformation to jet fuel compounds is in decrease of the oxygen content when ketones are formed. In addition, among alcohols, ethanol exhibited the highest selectivity over 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 while the presence of Pd/ZrO2 together with 1Rh1.52MnOx/SiO2 promoted ethanol selectivity above 250 °C. Interestingly, the main oxygenated product obtained over Rh4(CO)12SiO2 was ethanol at 220 °C under 1 bar using H2/CO ratio of 1 [13]. A very high carbon selectivity to C2+ oxygenates, 74.5 % has been obtained over Rh nanoparticles (2 nm) supported on mesoporous silica [12]. This catalyst exhibited mesoporous structure and different manganese oxides according to XPS analysis. The role of manganese as an oxophilic component was to promote tilted adsorption of C-O and its dissociation [35], which is beneficial for C2+ oxygenates formation. For 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 a very high methane conversion was obtained (Fig. 15a). Only traces of alkenes were also formed with their amounts decreasing upon increasing temperature and conversion (Fig. 15b). The highest selectivity among oxygenated products was obtained for methanol followed by propanol. The selectivity to oxygenated products decreased at high conversion at 300 °C as expected (Fig. 15c). The space-time yield (STY) of alcohols and acetic acid is plotted as a function of CO conversion ( Fig. 16). The highest STY yield of alcohols, 0.15 g/(gcat.h) in the current work was obtained with 1Rh1.5MnOx/SiO2+ 2 Pd/ZrO2 at 300 °C, while the second best catalyst was 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 giving at the same temperature STY of 0.11 g/(gcat.h) for alcohols. As a comparison with the literature, the highest STY of C2+ oxygenates, 0.23 (g/cat/h) yield was obtained with Rh-Mn/SiO2 catalyst with the weight ratio of 3.75 ( Table 6) [22], while in the current case the weight ratio of Rh/Mn was 0.75 giving a lower STY of oxygenates. For the best catalyst the maximum for hydrogen consumption in TPR was obtained at 90 °C, while the peak was shifted to a higher temperature with increasing Mn loading due to the interactions between Rh and Mn [22]. The corresponding alpha value for oxygenated products for 1.5 wt% Rh-0.4 wt% MnOx/SiO2 decreased with increasing temperature from 0.29 to 0.099 in the temperature range of 230–290 °C [22], while in the current case the alpha value was higher ( Table 7, Fig. S17, S18). It should also be noted that in the current case the catalyst contained 1.3 wt% Rh and 1.85 wt% Mn according to SEM-EDX analysis (Table S4). A higher amount of Mn used in the current work can suppress the chain termination step occurring via hydrogenation over Rh. In addition, it was stated in [18] that MnOx facilitates not only easier CO dissociation, but also stabilizes non-dissociatively adsorbed CO which in turn enhances CO insertion forming CHxCO* species. A high alpha value for oxygenates of 0.66 was reported over Rh-CoMn with H2/CO ratio of 1 [8], which might be caused by the presence of cobalt. In [10] also an optimum weight ratio of Rh/Mn equal to 3 gave the highest oxygenate selectivity, while with more manganese only methanol was formed among oxygenates and more CO2. The chain growth probability value for 1Rh5Co/ZrO2 was also rather high, especially at 300 °C (Table 7), which is supported by DRIFTS results showing a peak at 2060 cm−1 which could be assigned to Co(0001) active for the chain growth [56]. On the other hand, LaRh0.8Co0.2O3/SiO2 was very selective to alcohols at 280 °C (Table 6, entry 4) [63]. This catalyst exhibited also small metal particles (1.6 −2 nm) and due to La addition also a rather high basicity. It was stated in [61] that the bimetallic Rh-Co catalyst promotes formation of isolated Co0 sites and suppresses formation of hydrocarbons. If comparing the Rh/Co ratio, the best catalyst in [63] contained the Rh/Co molar ratio of 0.2, while in the current case for 1Rh5Co/SiO2 it was only 0.13, most probable not efficiently suppressing formation of isolated Co0. 4 Conclusions Several bi- and multimetallic Rh-based catalysts supported on SiO2 and ZrO2 were prepared by impregnation, characterized and tested in syngas transformation to higher alcohols in the temperature range of 225–300 °C under 30 bar with H2/CO ratio of 2. Metal particle sizes in all fresh catalyst were very small, not visible in XRD measurements. However, some sintering occurred during the experiment for all other catalyst except Rh-MnOx/SiO2. In addition, low activity for Rh-Cu/ZrO2 was originating from agglomeration of catalyst particles. The catalytic activity was not correlating with the degree of metal reduction. The highest activity was obtained over Rh-Co/ZrO2 catalysts, which was also relatively selective, 38 % to ethanol at 58 % CO conversion at 275 °C corresponding to the chain growth probability β for alcohols of 0.35. In addition, Rh-MnOx/SiO2 gave the β value of 0.41 at CO conversion of 19 % at 275°C. It should, however, be pointed out here that Rh-MnOx/SiO2 produced substantially amounts of acetic acid, which is not a desired product in fuel. Rh-MnOx/SiO2 catalyst did not suffer from metal sintering, while especially agglomeration and sintering of metal particles were observed for Rh-Cu/ZrO2, which was not active. To suppress acetic acid formation, Rh-MnOx/SiO2 catalyst was combined with Pd/ZrO2 resulting in formation of a lower amount of acetic acid and giving the highest space-time yield of alcohols, 0.15 g/(gcat .h) at 300 °C at 38 % CO conversion, while only Rh-MnOx/SiO2 under the same conditions STY of 0.09 g/(gcat .h) at 34 % CO conversion. On the other hand, Rh-Co/ZrO2 was very active giving at 84 % CO conversion level STY of alcohols ca. 0.11 0.09 g/(gcat .h). CRediT authorship contribution statement Pasi Virtanen: Investigation. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of syngas into higher alcohols was examined using bimetallic Rh-Co, Rh-Cu, and multimetallic RhCuPd catalysts, all of which were supported on ZrO2. This process was also studied using a MnOx-promoted Rh/SiO2 catalyst. These experiments were conducted within a temperature range of 225–300 °C, under a pressure of 30 bar, and with a H2/CO ratio of 2. The catalysts were characterized using a variety of physicochemical methods, including Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), X-ray Diffraction (XRD), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and Carbon Monoxide Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (CO DRIFTS). The Rh particle sizes in the fresh catalysts were found to be less than 3 nm. The Rh-Co catalyst supported on ZrO2 exhibited the highest selectivity to ethanol, achieving 38 % at a CO conversion rate of 58 % at 275 °C. This catalyst also demonstrated a chain growth probability of 0.35 for alcohols. A slightly higher chain growth probability was observed with the Rh-MnOx/SiO2 catalyst, although this also resulted in the formation of substantial amounts of acetic acid. Interestingly, this acetic acid could be converted into ketones when RhMnOx was used in conjunction with Pd/ZrO2.

coredata.dc:title: Transformation of syngas to valuable oxygenated products over Rh-MnOx/SiO2, Rh-Co/ZrO2 and Rh-Cu/ZrO2 catalysts
